newsitem.title: UK: Goldman Sachs committed to base metal trading.
newsitem.headline: Goldman Sachs committed to base metal trading.

text.p: Major investment house Goldman Sachs dismissed earlier talk swirling around the London Metal Exchange (LME) that it was considering downgrading its role in base metals trading.
Reinforcing this view a source at Goldman said a managing director of Goldman Sachs, Chris Carrera, had taken over market operations in London. He was recently based in the U.S.
"The move of Carrera is the strongest indication that Goldman is totally committed to base metals trading," the source said.
Carrera will head all activities in London concerning base metals trading.
"Goldman Sachs refutes in the strongest terms that they are running down their base metals activities," the source said.
Earlier on the LME floor some senior traders had voiced concern over the position of Goldman Sachs in the market.
The copper market has been unpredictable and volatile all year, particularly since the Sumitomo Corp copper scandal in June.
Sumitomo fired its head trader Yasuo Hamanaka, alleging he admitted running up losses of $2.6 billion in unauthorised copper trading.
"The move of Carrera has no repeat no reflection on the Sumitomo affair," the source commented.
Copper prices slumped from above $2,700 in April, down to $1,745 in June, then rising strongly to $2,313.
Copper's backwardation was erased in September, only to flare up during the autumn months.
Earlier this month, Lehman Brothers Commodities quit the LME floor, although traders said their departure did not reflect losses, as Lehman's metals business this year had been profitable.
Other LME ring-dealing companies have also shed staff, but some LME member firms, both on and off the floor, are still expanding.
